Term.Name: Audio
Term.Definition: Usages of languages for audio
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Main Original Language
Term.Definition: The language in which the content/resource was originally created.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Main Dubbed Language
Term.Definition: The language in which the audio track / dialogues, etc. have been dubbed. The term most commonly refers to the substitution of the voices of the actors shown on the screen by those of different performers speaking a different language. The practice also involves the rerecording of audio segments and then synchronizing the recording with the existing footage.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Additional Original Language
Term.Definition: An additional original language in which the audio track / dialogues have been created e.g. in countries with several official languages.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Additional Dubbed Language
Term.Definition: An additional original language in which the audio track / dialogues have been dubbed.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Descriptive Video Information
Term.Definition: DVI - Audio description for the visually impaired

Term.Name: Supplemental commentary

Term.Name: Director's commentary

Term.Name: Voice over
Term.Definition: Voice-over (also known as off-camera or off-stage commentary) is a production technique where a voice - that is not part of the narrative (non-diegetic) - is used in a radio, television production, filmmaking, theatre, or other presentations.[1] The voice-over may be spoken by someone who appears elsewhere in the production or by a specialist voice actor. It is pre-recorded and placed over the top of a film or video and commonly used in documentaries or news reports to explain information. There are many potential applications for using voice-over.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Dubbed Commentary

Term.Name: Dubbed Dialogue

Term.Name: Caption
Term.Definition: Indicates the usage of the language for captions, i.e. for hard-of hearing. Describes one language of the caption information included with the program (optional). The type of the caption information associated with the program is denoted by the closed attribute. Closed captions can be turned on or off by the user, while open captions (or subtitles) are part of the picture itself and remain visible.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Definition: Indicates the usage of the language for open captions

Term.Name: Closed Caption

Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Supplemental

Term.Name: Subtitles
Term.Definition: Indicates the usage of the language for subtitles, i.e. for translation purposes. Closed subtitles can be turned on or off by the user, while open subtitles are part of the picture itself and remain visible.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Open Subtitles

Term.Name: Closed Subtitles

Term.Name: Song Lyrics
Term.Definition: Indicates the use of the language for the lyrics of songs included in the content. For example a programme covering a concert by Pavarotti from La Scala may have original dialogue in Italian, Commentary in English and feature song lyrics in French, Spanish and German
